Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Roll-to-roll Solvent-free Fabrication of Asymmetric Porous Membrane for Low-cost High-efficiency Fuel Cell Humidification

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) grant provides funding to investigate the formation mechanism of asymmetric membranes in a solvent-free fabrication approach and the water transport phenomena in such membranes, in order to develop a manufacturing process for low-cost, high-efficiency humidification systems for fuel cell vehicle applications. The asymmetric membranes will be fabricated using a roll-to-roll foaming process with non-equilibrium gas saturation and desorption. A physics-based multi-scale dynamic model for water vapor transport in porous media will be developed to guide the design of the membrane structure. A bubble growth model will be employed together with experimental studies to identify the optimal process conditions. The experiments will be conducted on a lab scale foaming apparatus that will be designed and built. The fabricated membranes will be characterized and evaluated in prototype humidifiers sized for fuel cell vehicles. This research will be conducted with close collaboration between university and industry research teams. The university team will focus on modeling and process development and the industry partner (Ford) will focus on system design and integration.
If successful, the results of this research will lead to a novel manufacturing process for asymmetric membranes that are suitable for fuel cell humidification applications. They will also lead to enhanced understanding of water vapor transport phenomena in porous media. The technology developed in this work will be transferrable to the automotive industry and contribute to reducing the cost of fuel cell vehicles and improving the competitiveness of domestic manufacturers. The developed manufacturing process can also be used to fabricate membranes for many other applications, such as water purification and gas separation. In addition, this research will provide a unique opportunity for undergraduate and graduate students to obtain experimental and analytical training in a collaborative environment with industry.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this GOALI research is to investigate fundamental mechanisms of asymmetric membrane formation in a solvent-free fabrication process and the water transport phenomena in such membranes in order to develop a manufacturing process for low-cost, high-efficiency fuel cell humidification.

During the course of this project, a modeling framework to analyze membrane performance during real time operation within a PEM fuel cell system was developed. A one-dimensional, two-phase mass transport model to describe the transient water transport inside porous media was created. A novel temporal varying and spatial constant computational structure was used to minimize the computational expense. The concept of using multiple control volumes to model a flow channel provides a detailed estimation of the humidification along the length of gas channels, which cannot otherwise be modeled appropriately without using computational fluid dynamics methods. Experimental validations have showed that the modeling methodology can accurately predict the water vapor levels along the channel and provide insights on local humidity condition. This modeling tool enables the first ever capability of not only fast screening the membrane material but also on-line monitoring of membrane health.

Alternative low cost membranes were explored for PEM fuel cell humidification systems to replace the current Nafion membrane. A Polyethersulfone (PES) membrane was created for the humidifier. Zeolite was successfully incorporated into PES films to enable water vapor transfer function. A novel manufacturing process based on environmentally benign solid state foaming was developed for fabrication of the zeolite loaded PES membranes. Testing of the foamed PES-zeolite membrane in our humidification analysis system indicates the PES-zeolite membrane is permeable to water vapor. Our analysis showed that the manufacturing process can be scaled for roll-to-roll production.  A provisional patent has been filed based on this research result.

The research results were presented to the researchers and engineers at Ford Motor Company. The novel membrane process technique developed from this research attracted much attention from the industry and efforts are being pursued to commercialize the material.

Two major outreach activities were conducted during the course of this project. First, one of the graduate students who work on this project has disseminated the research findings to high school students through participating in the GK12 program at the University of Texas at Austin. This GK12 program pairs graduate Fellows with STEM educators in Austin Independent School District, with the purpose of creating innovative professional development opportunities for Fellows and K12 teachers, enriching STEM education, and strengthening partnerships between UT and the local community. The graduate student worked independently with high school teachers to develop lessons activities and participated in classroom teaching. The cutting edging knowledge learned from this research was immediately transferred to the students through teaching modules. As a result, the high school students were inspired to pursue a career in science discovery and engineering innovation. Secondly, the PI and Co-PI participated in a summer camp program for K-6 students during the past four years. The program included presentations and hands-on modules related to renewable energy: 1) batteries? 2) fuel cells? 3) biology? and 4) chemistry. About 80 K-6 students went through the program each year.

At the end of this project, two Ph.D. dissertations and one master’s thesis were produced. Three journal articles and five refereed conference proceeding papers were published. Five graduate students were involved in various aspects of the project. Research results were incorporated into undergraduate and graduate teaching to enrich students learning experience. In summary, this project has enabled scientific exploration and added to the state of art knowledge of membrane development and humidification characterization. The developed modeling framework can be applied to model other porous media, such as lithium ion battery electrodes, water desalination membranes, and geological formations. The developed new material could be used for many applications that require selective water vapor transfer functionality. 

 


Last Modified: 08/31/2016
Modified by: Dongmei Chen

During the course of this project, a modeling framework to analyze membrane performance during real time operation within a PEM fuel cell system was developed. A one-dimensional, two-phase mass transport model to describe the transient water transport inside porous media was created. A novel temporal varying and spatial constant computational structure was used to minimize the computational expense. Experimental validations have showed that the modeling methodology can accurately predict the water vapor levels along the channel and provide insights on local humidity condition.
